question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The Masnavi contains a reference in the back that is especially important to look up, since Rumi makes many metaphors and references that those not familiar with aspects of the Islamic faith are likely to miss. Attar is more comprehensible but he is by nature a poet, and so should also be read in this way.Read the texts very carefully.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was phenomenal and so far my favorite class at Duke. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is quite difficult if you don't already have a strong foundation in history or 3D modeling. Experience with one or the other would suffice, but I struggled coming in with weak backgrounds in both. My best advice is to start the labs early and dedicate enough time to just playing around with the software and making mistakes. Do your best to bridge the gap between the 3D modeling and the lecture content so you aren't going into the final project unsure of where to begin.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- patronage dynamics in early modern art 
- educational and networking opportunities for early women artist 
- the way that sterotypes relating to motherhood  and household work affected early modern art

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was introduced to so many female artists but what I really enjoyed was learning about their faults. They are complex beings and as exceptional as they were they also were flawed in the same way that we celebrate male artists who are extremely problematic (Picasso…) so this was a great introduction to what women are capable of in the art world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about women in visual arts and their different roles as artists, patrons, collectors, etc.; different challenges they faced; how they have been represented historically; how traditionally gendered analyses have influenced popular narratives; and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about women artists, the contexts in which they operated, how to conduct visual analysis, and how to question existing art historical practices of telling women’s stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Visually analyzing art created by female artists, creating an art exhibit and understand museum layout, and speaking about how spotlight female artists

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I better understand now how to view art and appreciate it. I also know how to consider the history of the art when I look at it. I also better understand women's place in art history and how they were overlooked and what discrimination they faced.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about individual women artists, obstacles that they have faced throughout art history and ways in which they have met these challenges, and issues in art historical and museum practice regarding representation and treatment of women artists. The course explored many different ways in which women were involved in the visual arts in the early modern period: women as makers of art, women as patrons and collectors of art, and representations of women in the visual arts.

I also just want to say that this was a wonderful idea for a course and I hope that it is routinely offered in the future so that many more students can learn about this interesting and valuable topic!

I also learned many things about the process of creating books and how printing worked. This may seem like a weird thing to take from this class, but understanding how books were made really helps with analyzing the old architectural books that we got ahold of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class (or if not this one, something else with Dr. Beckwith)!! It’s one of my favorite classes I’ve taken at Duke. To be fair, I already knew I loved Shakespeare before I took the class, but it seems like even students who weren’t as experienced with Shakespeare enjoyed the class. You will have to do a lot of reading— it helps if you watch the plays instead of just reading them (take advantage of Duke Libraries’ access to wonderful productions by companies like the RSC, Stratford Festival of Canada, and Globe Theater), but also have a copy with good notes in the margins (like the Folger or Arden edition). There are only two major written assignments, which means that each one counts a lot in your grade, but I didn’t mind because it meant that for most of the course we could focus on reading the plays and discussing them in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Witten is super interested in what he is teaching which is probably the most effective way to engage your students. I loved discussions, and it was fun to watch clips from the films. I hesitate to say I would keep the same plays in future years, because as much as I enjoyed them all, I think it would be more fun for Professor Witten to get to keep teaching new plays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how Professor Witten kept the class very interactive and promoted collaboration among students. He was extremely energetic and excited about the material he was teaching, which made me look forward to this class every day!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that even though it was on the bigger end of a seminar we were able to still have the 'seminar' component through the use small groups and the teacher's ability to lead and engage the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think I mostly enjoyed the balance between professorial commentary and student talking, but sometimes I wish that we as students guided the discussion a little more. Sometimes it felt like our professor sort of wanted us to hit a certain point of view or answer, and I was uncertain of what we might be supposed to be getting at which made me hesitant to talk. I almost wish we got to start with some sort of gauge of how everyone felt about the play/film, and find points of discussion from there.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the balance of text and film was very good, and the separation of units made it so that a good mix of plays were covered. I liked that the course engaged with non-American content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Modern/contemporary application of Shakespeare as discussed through adaptation made it so clear how continuously relevant Shakespeare's stories are to us today, and have been across time. We were encouraged to form connections across the plays, bring in historical context, and reference Shakespeare's own personal history to inform our readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was made stimulating because it allowed me to examine Shakespeare through a variety of lenses, gaining an understanding of both the potential and limitations of Shakespeare's original source material. Additionally, the class's discussion-based nature made it stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Like I said, the mini lectures, the questions Derek asked, and also the fast pacing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions were quite stimulating. Particularly for some of the films, people got really excited debating about how things ought to be interpreted which is always a lot of fun. I also really enjoyed reading scenes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Witten provided us with very intellectual insights, deepening our thoughts about Shakespeare and the director's choices in films, as well as applying this to the historical context in which Shakespeare produced his plays.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The level of engagement with Shakespearian texts and films made my level of engagement very high, and as a result, I am now personally invested in learning Shakespearian literature

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The movies and plays picked out made the class stimulating. Additionally, I really liked the in class activities and gobbets as they made me think more critically as I was reading or watching the films. Our adaptations were also really fun to write and film!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course takes a lot of time outside of class, the content is very engaging and allows you to explore the subject in a way that is most interesting for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I really enjoyed this class, but it is key to make sure you manage your time well! Even though reading plays and watching films is mostly enjoyable, it is still time consuming and it might feel easy to let things fall by the wayside. It is also important to really think about your final paper throughout the semester. Because there isn't a ton of time to work on it in class, it's entirely up  to you to ensure you work on it in a timely manner while balancing your other coursework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! Derek is incredible at making Shakespeare accessible on every level, and you'll almost certainly fall in love with these plays if you weren't already convinced of Shakespeare's storytelling abilities. Discussions were always so much fun, even just listening - the work for this class was genuinely my favorite to complete out of all of my classes. The film selections are fantastic as well as we discuss across genre and culture. There's no reason not to take this course, especially if you're an English major!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class, whether or not you love Shakespeare. Derek's insight, as well as that of your classmates, will open your mind to interesting ways of interpreting Shakespeare's material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Whether or not you know anything about Shakespeare, you should definitely take this course! Professor Witten is super knowledgeable and friendly and really interested in what he teaches. I felt like I learned so much more than I could ever hope to from just reading or watching Shakespeare on my own.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I had read Shakespeare all throughout high school, but Professor Witten completely changes your perspective and understanding of his plays. I felt like I was reading entirely knew plays in his class, so I would absolutely recommend. Professor Witten is brilliant!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

This class was a lesson in analysis, not necessarily in a formal sense, but in the way of how to read analytically and form thoughts that effectively communicated this analysis. course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about love in all of its forms in the context of poetry, the bible, novels, and philosophy. I particularly loved Julian and Norwich, Plato's Symposium, and Iris Murdoch- and of course, ALL the Shakespeare we read was incredible!

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: i analyzed love through many medieval works, include a couple of contemporary ones, specifically iris murdoch. through these texts, i built a lexicon of love, building a bank of greek and latin words as they relate to love. i also improved my writing by synthesizing what i learned in two essays.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My ability to read — and to really digest my reading — improved drastically in this course. I say this as an avid reader, who has been an English major since the beginning of my college career. But I think the breadth of work we undertook for this course simply made me a better reader, a better scholar of literature.I learned, in this course, how to compare topics across different disciplines. Comparing Christian theology to Shakespeare's comedies seems a bit of a stretch, at first thought, but I have learned how to hold ideas up against one another even if they are different in form and subject. I loved that we read so many different types of literature in this class, from novel to drama to philosophy.I learned a lot about Christian philosophy, which I think is very necessary for an English major, and maybe not taught quite enough in other courses.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course I learned how to interpret philosophy and how to apply it to classical writings, such as Shakespeare, and more modern pieces. The course texts gave me a different perspective on religious texts and I believe that the course dynamic allowed for great conversation.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: dr. sarah beckwith had immense knowledge on all the course material, she was able to readily provide background and open discussion on any question we had. it made it a very good environment to learn about the works, because we were able to play around and mold our idea of them by our discussions in-class, while having a very knowledgeable resource there to keep us on track. the commonplace book kept you on task when it came to taking away themes that you worked with before, during and after analyzing the text. the essays pushed us to dive deeper into topics we were interested in as they were brought up in class discussion, leaving no loose ends as the course wrapped up.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that this class struck a nice balance between Professor Beckwith lecturing and us students discussing our own ideas. I often find that English classes tend to lean too far one way or the other. As much as I value the discussion of my peers, I want to be taught by my professor. This class achieved that balance perfectly — we discussed our thoughts, and debated them at times, but I also filled my notebook with lecture notes about the writers we engaged with.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the classroom environment Professor Beckwith created. We each had the freedom to say how we interpreted texts, even if we were not confident. The variety of texts made this course engaging and relevant. I definitely found that the things I was learning and the literature I was being exposed to were ideas that I was able to apply to contexts outside of our classroom. I do wish that we would spend more time on each texts, especially The Black Prince. Towards the end of the semester it felt like we were trying to get in as much information as possible, and didn't have the ability to explore texts the way that we were with Aristotle and Plato. Additionally, I think the set up of professor lecturing for 10 minutes and then giving us the opportunity to discuss was very effective and hearing the contexts of texts and how they have been interpreted throughout time allowed me to feel more confident in my discussion. Lastly, I appreciated that there was so much freedom in the essay prompts.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Beckwith is brilliant. I could sit back and hear her thoughts on all the texts all day if that were a class option.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.

response_text: this is just the key to life but start early, ask questions often, and ENGAGE! engaging allows you to actually take something from the course versus just feeling like you're being lectured on shakespeare. starting early avoids stress and leaves room for office hours. asking questions demonstrates engagement and shows that you've worked with the text yourself.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely encourage another student to take this course. Prof. Beckwith's focus on love managed to tie together centuries of literary tradition in a way that never seemed forced, even if we spanned so many years and so many types of literature. Learning Shakespeare with Professor Beckwith is a real pleasure, especially when she teaches his work through one specific lens, like she did with love in this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think creatively, to imagine while reading and make thematic connections between the works that I was introduced to during this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned to closely read fantasy literature, analyze common themes throughout fantasy fiction, and discuss how these themes are subverted or altered in modern fantasy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to view fantasy from historical epics as an insight into how societies were structured. How to discuss on topics that have conflicting scholarly reviews and find meaning in it. How to marry ancient and modern story telling and what it tells us about how society and pop culture has changed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to analyze fantastical texts for their various elements, and appreciate them for their literary value. I learned how to analyze specific aspects of fantasy, like kings and kingdoms, bloodlines, and the roles of women. I learned how to write about fantasy and enhanced my critical writing skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into how fantasy narratives have evolved over time, changing from fairly basic stories about invincible heroes to wel rounded stories with nw worlds of their own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about how overarching themes connect with different pieces of texts or films. I also worked on my writing skills since we had to write a paper (and received some good constructive feedback), along with improving my teamwork skills and communication thanks to discussing with a person around me every class and working in a group project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me to better analyze fantasy literature and media, specifically by looking at motifs in the genre, comparing works to other fantasy media, and seeing how works fit into and deviate from typical fantasy tropes and storylines.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand fantasy beyond what is being presented. There are a lot of underlining themes and motifs that I never considered when reading, watching, and interpreting such works. I gained a deeper knowledge for identifying these key themes and how characters operate. I think my critical skills of reading and writing improved as well as overall analysis of these fantastical works.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the construction of fantasy and it's associated themes, tropes, characteristics. I learned how to analyze movies and text. I learned that evaluating fantasy as "escapism" is a limited viewpoint.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to approach unfamiliar stories with antiquated language, how to think and write about fantasy, new exposure to different definitions and styles of fantasy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I like the material we had to encounter. It was fantasy but we used it to compare it to everyday events. It was really interesting. I learned how personal experience affected how you interacted with each piece. I learned more about d&d from an academic standpoint. I learned how to compare and contrast each piece effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the origins of many tropes I've taken for granted. I learned how to draw parallels between stories and modern societal problems and problems of the time. I furthered my understanding of fantasy as a medium for story telling and the tethers between myth, history, and story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I learned over this course were using my ability to think critically about media, understanding how people's perspectives influence genre, and how to write comparative essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How do evaluate beyond the surface-level descriptions of fantasy and dive into the meaning behind objects and characters
2. Comparing different stories in order to define common themes in fantasy 
3. How to analyze fantasy films

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became much more open-minded through this course. I also developed my skills in fast-paced reading and analysis. Lastly, I learned a lot about how to relay information in an informative yet still highly engaging setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the different tropes and themes that make up the fantasy genre and how cultural products deconstruct these things in modern times compared to years ago.I learned about Dungeons and Dragons, its history and development, how to play it in an actual campaign, and how it has influenced the mainstream cultural sphere of fantasy and been influenced in return.I learned how to analyze fantasy works on a deeper level, be it text, film, or photos, to find what about the fantasy reflects real-world ideals and how they sometimes mirror movements happening when fantasy cultural products are released.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about Viking technology and how they used their warships to become successful warriors across north america, europe, and asia. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned included: the structure and teachings of Norse mythology, the simultaneously simple and complex aspects of Viking society (such as their legal system of private enforcement), and the Vikings sheer power and might in conquest, as they migrated and expanded across much of Europe, and even Asia and North America.

course: HISTORY-254-01 : EUROPE IN THE MIDDLE AGES.HISTORY-254-01.MEDREN-254-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I don't believe that we need to study history only for it's connections to the present, but even so, at the start of every course I think professors need to frame the class around a "why" -- that is to say, why do I need to learn what this class will teach me, and why does it matter. I would argue the best classes continue to reinforce this "why" every week, and build upon it, to make sure students continue to clearly see the importance of what they are learning. Otherwise, the class is bound to feel like a waste of time, especially to those students taking it to fulfill a credit or a major requirement. Emily tried to do a little bit of that by having us brainstorm myths we had believed about the middle ages, but this was framed more as a reason for us to be excited about the class, not the reason why we need to learn the things she taught us. I found myself pretty bored and dragging my feet through a lot of this class because it honestly felt a little pointless to me without having a clear understanding of why I should care about a bunch of random kings and successive iterations of Christian doctrine. Not because I believe these things are inherently boring or pointless, but because I was never given a reason to see them as actually important. Again, focusing less on granular details from this broad time period and more on broader trends or viewing it through distinct analytical lenses that reveal larger historical insights might lend itself to highlighting this "why."

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
This class was well thought out and well organized. The topics flowed from week to week and the source materials were engaging. I enjoy Professor Robisheaux's mode of teaching, his way of telling stories, and the addition of art and images to the lectures. The materials were readily accessible through Canvas, and the assignments, as well as his feedback, were thorough. 
Additionally, this class was assigned an undergraduate teaching fellow who was encouraged by Professor Robisheaux to share his perspectives on how to do history, how to read different source materials, and how to structure academic writing. Though I had time conflicts during many of his available hours, he made an effort to be accessible for feedback and assistance on upcoming writing assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course content was just fascinating, and Dr. Robisheaux is a fantastic story teller, which adds a level of excitement to everything we learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class approached the Reformation, its ideas, its outcomes, and its violence with a fresh perspective. We thought widely about the phenomenon of the Reformation, while also pointing our attention to the lived experiences of people during this time. Martin Luther, in this course, was expanded from a man who scorned the Catholic Church and wrote ninety-five theses into a young adult in crisis, a tormented thinker, and a figure with complex, oftentimes harmful views of those of varying faiths and identities. Many major players in Europe during this time period received this treatment in the course, but the everyday person was not left out of the story, either. Professor Robisheaux made a pointed effort to consider the laity, the women, the craftspeople, and those from minority groups in his storytelling. The conversations that were inspired by these diverse stories, and insightful perspectives were one of the highlights of my semester. There was always a new point of view, a new source to analyze, and a new method for understanding to be discovered in this class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Taking perspectives of several sides of the Reformation made this class stimulating. I think this was most effective when we tried to see the perspective of each writer/group instead of being quick to dismiss them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course. It's the essential history course experience, complete with engaging historical themes and a professor that truly cares about the development and ambitions of all his students.

response_text: This is a rewarding, fulfilling course that will expand your understanding of the Reformation story. Familiar figures will be complicated, examined, and humanized. Expect to complete a decent amount of readings that inform deep class discussions. Professor Robisheaux is a brilliant storyteller, well-informed about the historical characters in the stories he tells; you learn so much just by listening.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about the works of Machiavelli, Guicciardini, Cellini, mid-to-late Renaissance Italy (politics, literature, culture), and the applicability of those politics today. Machiavelli and Guicciardini, in particular, are timeless authors; their works are so applicable to the current era, and there's a lot of lessons that can be drawn by analyzing them (those times and these times are surprisingly similar, especially in terms of political crises).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about Renaissance politics and society in the context of today's world, and history and society in general.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Machiavelli, Guicciardini, and Cellini. I learned about the role of art in politics and politics in art. I learned about the history of Florentine politics in the 1400s-1500s.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Renaissance Italy, the great thinkers of that period (Machiavelli, Guicciardini, Bruni, etc.), and I learned how to engage with that historical style of writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - Reading historical texts, writing a history paper, viewing historic political thinkers through the lens of history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned, specifically for history classes, was how to immerse myself in the times of a piece and use the context of politics and religion to inform my readings. Furthermore, I was able to develop skills in nuanced reading and picking out subtle changes in authorial intent in writings. The class definitely challenged me to think in a less empirical way.

response_text: We explored how politics and historical circumstances impacted the writings and art of Machiavelli, Guicciardini, Cellini, and other Renaissance thinkers and artists, which included analyzing political treatises, pieces of art, and studying the historical background of the High Renaissance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In terms of specifics, I learned about the four voyages of Columbus within the variety of historical and cultural contexts that they took place in.  In the broader sense, I developed abilities for considering and thinking about historical texts.  I was also encouraged throughout the course to focus and work on my own reading habits and time management as a graduate student.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I have been exposed to an entire array of writing and readings that I had never previously encountered, and that is so exciting. The ideas and beliefs that I had upon joining the class in relation to Columbus have further developed and are much more informed. This course has helped my thinking of connected histories and the ways in which we read/write/do history. The contexts that gave birth to Columbus have been very eye-opening and give solid grounds to how a character, as emblematic (in its many definitions) as Columbus, came to be and evolve into what it did. My thinking is certainly more robust when considering Columbus and his contemporaries.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor facilitated conversations about the readings and provided additional knowledge about the subjects that we learned about. I loved it and think he should keep doing that in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the intention behind crafting an interdisciplinary classroom, made possible by crosslisting this course across many departments and opening it to UNC students. I loved studying these historic texts and secondary sources with students outside of my own program, which allowed for new insights and understandings that have shaped the way I approach work in my home discipline. Dr. Martin created a lot of pathways for us to engage with the material, and I appreciated the weekly message board assignment as it allowed for me to engage my classmates and begin a dialogue even before I entered the classroom. This was especially meaningful for a weekly seminar where I only see my classmates once a week, and want to make the most of the time together. Dr. Martin did a great job lightly facilitating the class, but otherwise emphasizing a student-led discussion of the materials. He never discouraged us from pressing a topic or conversation further, even if it didn't directly address the overall seminar topic, and these conversations always ended up being very rich and linking us back to the ideas and concerns that make us interested in studying Columbus in the first place.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I always appreciate seminar style courses.  Hearing the thoughts of my fellow classmates helps me to figure out and puzzle through and at times challenge (in good ways) my own take-aways from weekly readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to engage with an arduous piece of literature from seven centuries ago, analyzing many political, theological and ethical themes that are relevant for today's world. I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: College students are so used to handling books that it is not surprising that they take them for granted. Paleography is a great way to learn how concretely such an important tool for learning came into being and has come down to us preserving for centuries and centuries texts that we can read today with a simple google search. Confronting the somewhat alien materiality and its challenges can be useful and humbling for Classics students but also for any other student.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the different tropes and themes that make up the fantasy genre and how cultural products deconstruct these things in modern times compared to years ago.I learned about Dungeons and Dragons, its history and development, how to play it in an actual campaign, and how it has influenced the mainstream cultural sphere of fantasy and been influenced in return.I learned how to analyze fantasy works on a deeper level, be it text, film, or photos, to find what about the fantasy reflects real-world ideals and how they sometimes mirror movements happening when fantasy cultural products are released.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class we learned about what fantasy is and how different elements of fantasy serve as metaphors for the human condition. We also learned about how different themes in fantasy all build on eachother historically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned how fantasy is a reflection of real ideas, struggles, desires, and more in a secondary world. We learned how to compare texts across medium and time, and how to glean the main themes from fantasy works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the lectures, they were very stimulating. I also thought the readings were interesting and actually pertinent. I also liked visiting the rare books library and attending the Iftar. More experiences like that during the course or as supplements would be really interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the reading to help facilitate learning in lectures and I also appreciated that we had a guided reflection to fill out about the readings. It held me accountable to do my readings and engage with them. I also just enjoyed the overall structure of the class and how it would shift from each religion and how there would aslo be days where our professors would teach on a common topic. Additional to the structure I enjoyed that there were only two major assignments to do throughout the whole semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were "good" for the most part. It's definitely the right idea, but sometimes the instructions were vague and the links were hard to find. I would certainly keep these graded readings, and expand on the feedback. The lectures were always excellent and the professors always came OVERLY prepared. It was impressive and refreshing to be taught by professors who had too many slides and could talk for hours on their subject. Don't change a thing about the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors would often give us handouts to follow along easier in class, and they also would pick students to read slides, which was helpful in keeping us engaged. The reading responses  also helped us come into class with a basis of knowledge on the subject that was to be discussed that day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

You can tell that they are enthusiastic about their work and sharing what they have worked on for so long. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Engage with it the best you can! If you do it could be one of the most interesting and fun classes you'll take in your time at Duke. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify different sections on pages of the Qur'an, supposed discrepancies in the Bible, and the discourse surrounding the interpretation of "slave" or "servant" in the Bible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze texts and apply them across different cultures. I learned how to write well thought through research papers. I learned how to engage with different opinions than my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how complex religion and scripture is 
- the importance of understanding the limitations of scripture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how scriptures of Islam, Christianity, and Judaism are compiled and interpreted. I also learned about the basic structure of each religious text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text
Learned different methods of interpretation
learned the history that led to the evolution of these different interpretations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at scriptures from a historical and critical perspective rather than a religious one
I learned about the canonization of each scripture and the complexities behind each
I learned of how each of the religions cope with issues and how they try to modernize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to distinguish between religion and scripture from a scholarly perspective. We learned different words in Greek, Hebrew, and Arabic. We also learned about different key figures in each religious tradition.

response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

- how complex religion and scripture is

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned fascinating ways of how seemingly different fields were intimately connected during the Renaissance, and learned about musical composers in new and interesting ways.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply historical thinking skills to music, how music was viewed as medicine, and how music was considered a part of the sciences during the Renaissancd.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a massive amount about the connection between science, religion, and the arts during the Renaissance.
2. I learned how music was treated far differently in the past, being seen more as a means of medicine and personal growth than simply pitches that are made for hearing.
3. The Renaissance is much more complex than one might initially think, and even if some of the ideas are bizarre in today's context, the thought process and curiosities of ancient musicians and thinkers were truly ingenius.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Research writing ability, analysis of both primary and secondary sources specifically with texts in a different language at the Rubenstein, the interconnectiveness of academic subjects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical thinking skills, analyzing primary sources to reveal broader historical trends, writing research papers based on primary sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Professor Robisheaux's course, I learned how to historically analyze primary sources, create my own insights of these sources, as well as describe my findings in a concise way.  This has been the most thought-provoking history class I've ever taken, and I learned so much about history and how to think about it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As far as knowledge we delved deep into influential renaissance polymaths such as Leonardo Di Vinci, Paracelsus, Galileo, and Maria Sylliba. Through this we connected deep societal themes such as the interweaving of religion, science, and arts. I learned how to reflect back on history and connect themes across time. I also learned how to construct and produce research papers, specifically dealing with creating meaningful questions which have significance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Engagement with primary sources, developing an open research mindset, & the interconnectedness of everything (among disciplines, people & the universe, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to understand how the upbringing and environment of different polymaths in the Renaissance shaped their theories and role in the scientific community. I learned how to effectively and efficiently craft an essay by synthesizing resources, generating a logical outline of the essay with ample evidence, and writing out the argument in essay format. Examining primary sources in the Rubenstein library has allowed me to be more connected with life in the Renaissance and place myself in that era to view issues through a more historical lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing skills, learned how to be a better participant in class discussions and think historically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to examine primary sources both in their content and in their physical characteristics, furthering my understanding of historical research. Secondly, I learned how to go through the process of writing a true historical research paper. Previously I had written essays about history, but never had I really addressed a historical research problem of my own conception. Finally, I have learned to think differently about Renaissance history, primarily understanding that the relationship between religion and science was fundamentally different than today. It changed my perspective entirely.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I devloped critical reading skills, especially of primary sources, as well as analytical writing skills. Reading primary works by the figures we were studying helped bring the historical figures into a more familiar, personal light.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The writing process is very well-refined where there is ample time for drafts and feedback

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt that the seminar style of this class was very helpful for my own learning because I could head my peers' ideas and insights, not just my own. I also very much appreciated that Professor Robisheaux was almost always available to help with writing, editing, and revising. My writing improved a great deal in this course because of his dedication to helping me become the best writer I could.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Robisheaux is an amazing teacher and an even better person.  He was always available outside of class and willing to hear your opinion on what we were discussing.  I'd keep everything the same for future years because in this class everything about the course allows students to make their own analyses and interpretations of history, whereas in high school you really had to agree with everything the teacher said in order to succeed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoy the small class size as we all get familiar and more comfortable with each other. Professor Robisheaux also takes it upon himself to be intuitive and ensure everyone is involved with every class. I also value the classes we take to peer review. Hearing different perspectives from my peers about my work allows me to expand on it in original ways.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Open seminar format that's incredibly student-driven --all ideas are encouraged. Visits to the Rubenstein to engage with rare books helped us "step into" the past and feel the amount of time that has passed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Robisheaux led discussions in class which were very helpful in comparing and contrasting different perspectives of myself and those of my classmates. This allowed me to expand the horizons of my thinking and opened new ideas for discussion. The helpful guidelines for essay writing and the work-in-progress presentation was also helpful in helping us succeed in assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the seminar style of the class helped me stay engaged and learning. I think that conversational style is critical in forming your own opinions and expressing them clearly.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was phenomenal and so far my favorite class at Duke. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is quite difficult if you don't already have a strong foundation in history or 3D modeling. Experience with one or the other would suffice, but I struggled coming in with weak backgrounds in both. My best advice is to start the labs early and dedicate enough time to just playing around with the software and making mistakes. Do your best to bridge the gap between the 3D modeling and the lecture content so you aren't going into the final project unsure of where to begin.
